identificationModule.officialTitle: Are Spatial and Temporal Muscle Synergy Modules Related to Functional Ability After Stroke?

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The aim of this systematic review was to determine the number of muscle synergies and the distribution of muscle weightings in stroke patients during gait.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: The aim of this systematic review was to determine the number of muscle synergies and the distribution of muscle weightings in stroke patients during gait. Although literature has suggested that merging of synergies occurs after stroke and that a larger number of is associated with increased motor function if compared with healthy adults. IIt is still unknown if this hypothesis is also relevant when comparing different functional levels within a stroke population and what functional impact of altered synergies on walking behavior is.

armGroups.label: Stroke
armGroups.description: Individuals suffered from a haemorrhagic or ischaemic stroke. Diagnosis has to be confirmed on the basis of CT or MRI imaging.

armGroups.label: Healthy adults
armGroups.description: Healthy individuals without any neurological or orthopaedic disorder that could influence motor performance and balance

primaryOutcomes.measure: Amount of muscle synergies derived by non-negative matrix factorization
primaryOutcomes.description: Spatial characteristic of muscle synergy compared to healthy adults: the amount of synergies during walking in stroke subjects, the amount of muscles in one synergie and which muscles in one synergy
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Once, in the week of inclusion

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Distribution of muscle synerigies derived by non-negative matrix factorization
secondaryOutcomes.description: Temporal characteristic of muscle synergy compared to healthy adults: When are these synergies active during the gait cycle (100%).
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Once, in the week of inclusion

eligibilityModule.studyPopulation: Healthy Volunteers: community sample Stroke: Rehabilitation Hospital RevArte, primary care clinic
